TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesday: A change of pace

Articles.Content:
The last few updates have made us fall in love with air and sea again. Now, we get toys for solid ground

With sensible grip, there may actually be a purpose for suspension geometry - the rotate widget will allow us to dial in camber, kickup, toe in and toe out, maybe even Ackerman etc.

33 minutes ago, colmo said:

maybe even Ackerman etc.

Don't remember exactly which one, but one of the dev notes from early in the unity 5 upgrade, when this whole business with redoing the wheels first came up, HarvesteR said that Ackerman would be built into the new wheel mechanics. Not sure if that's still true or not, but it was planned at one point.

4 minutes ago, FullMetalMachinist said:

Don't remember exactly which one, but one of the dev notes from early in the unity 5 upgrade, when this whole business with redoing the wheels first came up, HarvesteR said that Ackerman would be built into the new wheel mechanics. Not sure if that's still true or not, but it was planned at one point. 

Is Ackerman even necessary since it probably doesn't model tire wear? I guess it's cool to see the inside tire turn more than the outside and it's a pretty straight forward equation to calculate nominal Ackerman but I'm wondering the necessity.

7 minutes ago, Racescort666 said:

but I'm wondering the necessity.

No idea, you'll have to ask the devs on that one . I only remember it being mentioned, and as I'm mobile instead of at my pc, I won't be trying to find it right now.

1 hour ago, FullMetalMachinist said:

Don't remember exactly which one,

From the 24th of June 2015

Except in question for easier reading;

On 6/22/2015 at 9:02 AM, SQUAD said:

Apart from that, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m also implementing a new steering module. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve always had this peeve about the old system that it required you to manually set up each wheel to be inverted or un-inverted, with no good way to tell which way was which. The new steering module uses a new method to calculate which way each wheel should turn based on the steering input, which is used to figure out where the commanded turn Ã¢â‚¬ËœpivotÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ point would be, and that is then used to make each wheel rotate to face sideways to that point, so regardless of where or how they are mounted on a vessel, wheels will always respond properly to steer the right way (There will still be steering invert and toggle tweaks though, just in case). Another benefit of this approach is that Ackermann steering happens as a consequence.

On 1/27/2016 at 6:36 PM, Captain Sierra said:

THis requires KSP to model surface hardness. While something I would full well support, its probably asking too much for 1.1 given how much is already coming. But yes Squad, you should do this.

Why not pre-model surface hardness into a table of friction coefficients separated by "biome"? Just doing this would give polar regions and minmus ice flats different friction properties.

3 hours ago, ExtremeSquared said:

Why not pre-model surface hardness into a table of friction coefficients separated by "biome"? Just doing this would give polar regions and minmus ice flats different friction properties.

Hmm, it's a great issue  - that "biome" still equals geology.

Messing biomes with physics should make things even even worse.

Edited January 28, 2016 by _Astra_
typo

Wheels! My fleet of rovers will finally work properly! Wheels! HAHAHAHA! All the biome science shall belong to me!  

I am totally building an ultra-endurance rover and shipping in straight to Duna the instant 1.1 comes out.

13 hours ago, NoMrBond said:

From the 24th of June 2015

Except in question for easier reading;

 

Cool! Thanks for finding this, I understand now. It's not that they need Ackerman steering geometry it just happens from the way the steer angle is calculated.

It is a little bit more complex for 4 wheel steering (or more than 4) but it's calculating nominal wheel steer angle to get you this:

The weird part of this is that we've been talking about (and calculating) Ackerman geometry at work for the last few days. It's nice that in KSP each wheel can rotate independently of the others and you can get perfect ackerman at every steer angle. We're trying to get an approximate for a given range of steer angles to cut down on tire wear.

Oddly enough, one of the major appeals of Ackermann steering in KSP (Wheels turn concentrically, so they don't build up stress as inner wheels push out and outer wheels push in) is being eliminated because they will slide a bit. Very interesting.

So I know nothing about the dev process and have no idea what the differences between QA, experimentals, etc. are. 

My question is: At this point in time, does SQUAD have a version of KSP that is running (not necessarily stable) in Unity 5 64bit?

I'd love to hear the performance compared to 1.0.5 flying high part count ships.

4 minutes ago, KerbonautInTraining said:

So I know nothing about the dev process and have no idea what the differences between QA, experimentals, etc. are. 

My question is: At this point in time, does SQUAD have a version of KSP that is running (not necessarily stable) in Unity 5 64bit?

I'd love to hear the performance compared to 1.0.5 flying high part count ships. 

In either last week's, or the week before, dev notes, they said that they have a windows 64 bit build that is stable (so far). So that's good news. Unfortunately they've been pretty tight lipped about specific performance increases, but there's plenty of speculation in one or two threads over in General KSP Discussion if you care to read it.

I must save this thread from its poemless state!

The rover wheels are bugged to hell

Hopefully fixed by Nathankell

Still so much work to do 

1.1 update, such ado

So close to release, yet so far away

Please tell me SQUAD surprise released it today 

Advertisment work starting in Europe

Development has slowed to the rate of syrup 

Darn humans forgot to make a poem this week

Superhuman performance, does the community seek.

Edited January 28, 2016 by Sanic

does SQUAD have a version of KSP that is running (not necessarily stable) in Unity 5 64bit

12 hours ago, _Astra_ said:

Hmm, it's a great issue  - that "biome" still equals geology.

Messing biomes with physics should make things even even worse.

That's why I put biome in quotes. They can still be called biomes if the entire KSP system is riddled with anaerobic fungus and bacteria. As it stands, there is no place in the stock Kerbol system that doesn't contain alien life, which is sort of fun.

To be fair, it is just a game, but it would be great if they put out a "classroom edition" that can be used to teach physics without botching biology terms.

On 26/1/2016 at 11:12 PM, SQUAD said:

AeroGUI has been made a debug option from the aerodynamics tab of the debug toolbar. AeroGUI was originally written to help 1.0 aero QA and it’s been helpful in every QA session since, so ‘stockification’ of this development tool is worth the effort.

 

Will we finally be able to see the lift and drag generated by the wings?

I so look forward to the wheels on my Dres rovers working like... Wheels.  Sweet news Squad!  By chance will this mean having a 3 axle vehicle with the center axle at the center of turn of the vehicle, set to not turn, will actually be properly stable?  I so can't wait.  Got plenty of extreme terrain suspension system designs to implement on my rovers.  Just right now, the wheel system does not correlate with the results in the real world.  At least not when you use designs that are not conventional.

1 hour ago, Jakalth said:

I so look forward to the wheels on my Dres rovers working like... Wheels.  Sweet news Squad!  By chance will this mean having a 3 axle vehicle with the center axle at the center of turn of the vehicle, set to not turn, will actually be properly stable?  I so can't wait.  Got plenty of extreme terrain suspension system designs to implement on my rovers.  Just right now, the wheel system does not correlate with the results in the real world.  At least not when you use designs that are not conventional.

I'm more worried that the change to the wheels will make what I am used to completely useless.  I have at least 100 hours of wheel roving, possibly double that, mostly on the Mün and Kerbin, but also on Duna, Eve, Vall, Minmus, and Moho.
But I'm willing to relearn, as long as the system is decent and you can rove more than 3min before something continuously breaking (repairable by Bill or not!).

Wheels you say...

http://imgur.com/gallery/O2wazhq

 

 

Edited January 29, 2016 by Darnok

On ‎1‎/‎26‎/‎2016 at 5:12 PM, SQUAD said:

A wide range of issues was fixed this week: from initialization issues that were caused by oversights from six months ago to more bizarre bugs such as the one that caused parked wheels to start drifting. We never quite discovered the root cause of the issue, but Felipe devised a plan (a very cunning plan) and simply corrected the phantom torque with an equal and opposite torque. Newton would be proud. The wheels now stay in place, which means that vehicles continue to not move as they should.

This sounds like the typical "treating the symptom rather than curing the cause" scenario. I have this bad feeling that eventually this will turn around to bite you.

Besides, I think it's a waste of system resources if the game needs to continuously calculate and apply a force to negate some phantom force (even if it only applies when you're on the ground)... It might be small overhead, but it just seems like bad programming practice to "brute force" the issue. I understand programming a complex system takes effort and everything. I'm hoping this is a VERY temporary workaround until an actual fix to the underlying cause to the problem can be applied. (Unless an actual fix can be devised due to the nature of the problem. Then workaround it is...)

Just out of curiosity, was the force always in a single vector/direction? Considering everything in the game is technically in motion other than the Sun, could it be a side affect of that? I could easily imagine that unless a set of wheels was locked into a certain frame of reference, the relative lack of precision in a physics algorithm could add up and emerge as a phantom force as it tries to sync the positions of 2 points independently in constant motion. I mean the surface of something like Kerbin is moving (rotation) while the body itself is as well (orbit). Trying to make sure friction forces apply correctly to ensure another body sitting on the surface is sync'ed properly in that frame of reference could cause issues, no?

6 hours ago, StahnAileron said:

Just out of curiosity, was the force always in a single vector/direction? Considering everything in the game is technically in motion other than the Sun, could it be a side affect of that?

Quite a while ago the physics engine was tweaked so the center of the universe is the active ship. Or something along those lines. 

Hopefully by the time this comes back to bite them they have tools to find the root cause.

(this is my 100th post on the forums)

Edited January 29, 2016 by KerbonautInTraining
